name: HD 30177
scenarioDescription:
The HD 30177 Exoplanetary System


Overview

HD 30177 is a star with 1.05 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.02 times its radius. It is located 181.60 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 2.525 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

HD 30177 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the HD 30177 system


HD 30177 b

HD 30177 b was discovered by the Anglo-Australian Telescope observatory using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 3.70 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HD 30177 b is 2741.796 times the mass of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, HD 30177 b is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.


HD 30177 c

HD 30177 c was discovered by the Multiple Observatories observatory using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 9.89 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HD 30177 c is 2416.7999999999997 times the mass of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, HD 30177 c is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system HD 30177, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Anglo-Australian Telescope.
